When questioned as to their university spirit, gold-diggers pour
forth a sad tale and bewail that no opportunity is offered them. When
a time comes, however, such as in the season ticket sale campaign,
when they might conveniently prove their worth, they throw up their
hands in horror and again become conspicuous by their failure to support. It is regrettable that the Hopkins campus has to boast of so
many members of the gold-digger species that it becomes necessary
to extend the season ticket sale campaign beyond the allotted time.

DANCES RESUMED
To remedy an ill, first remove the cause. It seems evident that
the plan of the Student Council to bar outsiders, except as guests of
Hopkins men, and to supervise conduct at dances on the campus
will eliminate all cause for future misdemeanors. As a whole, the
campus feels that supervision has been placed in the proper hands
and rejoices that dances are again to be held.
A clause in the constitution of the Student Council explains
that the Honor System extends to all matters on the campus that a
slip of gentlemanly conduct is as serious a violation of the Honor
System as "cribbing" in an examination. There is prevailing on the
campus a hazy conception of the exact nature and provisions of the
Student Council. For this reason, the News-Letter will publish the
Student Council's constitution in a subsequent issue.

SHAKESPEAREAN WEATHER—APRIL FIRST IN
HARMONY WITH APRIL FOOL TRADITIONS
It is not often that the elements
combine with human invention in
placing emphasis on a certain fact
or tradition. Only in Shakespearean plays do we really look for a
sympathy of the heavens with the
course of human events. But last
Tuesday the great stage in which
we live, the great drama of which
we are a part, was in complete
harmony with a human tradition
—April Fool's Day.
Driven by a biting northeast
wind that swept the Hopkins
campus, a snow that assumed blizzard proportions quickly concealed the fresh, green grass,

turned automobiles into fantastic
white objects suggestive of Arab
genii, and blanketed every object
exposed to the sky in a heavy
mantle. April, the month of
showers, April, the month of cool
mornings and balmy noondays,
April, commonly termed a Spring
month, started like December!
But therein lies the sympathy of
the elements. If Shakespeare had
seen the conditions on Tuesday,
he would have exclaimed, "Well
done! It is fitting that on April
Fool's Day men be fooled."
How many, we wonder, appreciate the true dramatic qualities
of Tuesday's snow?

Son of a London soap-boiler
who became AstronomerRoyal. At the age of 20 headed

The cometcame back
The great comet that was seen by William
of Normandy returned to our skies in 1910
on its eleventh visit since the Conquest.
Astronomers knew when it would appear,
and the exact spot in the sky where it
would first be visible.
Edmund Halley's mathematical calculation of the great orbit of this 76-year visitor—his scientific proof that comets are
part of our solar system—was a brilliant
application of the then unpublished Principia of his friend Sir Isaac Newton.

When questioned as to their university spirit, gold-diggers pour
forth a sad tale and bewail that no opportunity is offered them. When
a time comes, however, such as in the season ticket sale campaign,
when they might conveniently prove their worth, they throw up their
hands in horror and again become conspicuous by their failure to support. It is regrettable that the Hopkins campus has to boast of so
many members of the gold-digger species that it becomes necessary
to extend the season ticket sale campaign beyond the allotted time.

DANCES RESUMED
To remedy an ill, first remove the cause. It seems evident that
the plan of the Student Council to bar outsiders, except as guests of
Hopkins men, and to supervise conduct at dances on the campus
will eliminate all cause for future misdemeanors. As a whole, the
campus feels that supervision has been placed in the proper hands
and rejoices that dances are again to be held.
A clause in the constitution of the Student Council explains
that the Honor System extends to all matters on the campus that a
slip of gentlemanly conduct is as serious a violation of the Honor
System as "cribbing" in an examination. There is prevailing on the
campus a hazy conception of the exact nature and provisions of the
Student Council. For this reason, the News-Letter will publish the
Student Council's constitution in a subsequent issue.

SHAKESPEAREAN WEATHER—APRIL FIRST IN
HARMONY WITH APRIL FOOL TRADITIONS
It is not often that the elements
combine with human invention in
placing emphasis on a certain fact
or tradition. Only in Shakespearean plays do we really look for a
sympathy of the heavens with the
course of human events. But last
Tuesday the great stage in which
we live, the great drama of which
we are a part, was in complete
harmony with a human tradition
—April Fool's Day.
Driven by a biting northeast
wind that swept the Hopkins
campus, a snow that assumed blizzard proportions quickly concealed the fresh, green grass,

turned automobiles into fantastic
white objects suggestive of Arab
genii, and blanketed every object
exposed to the sky in a heavy
mantle. April, the month of
showers, April, the month of cool
mornings and balmy noondays,
April, commonly termed a Spring
month, started like December!
But therein lies the sympathy of
the elements. If Shakespeare had
seen the conditions on Tuesday,
he would have exclaimed, "Well
done! It is fitting that on April
Fool's Day men be fooled."
How many, we wonder, appreciate the true dramatic qualities
of Tuesday's snow?
